Award.AwardTitle: Geodynamic Models of Subsidence and Lithospheric Flexure at the ANDRILL Drill Sites: Implications for Cenozoic Tectonics and Ice Sheet History
Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
This research will place the subsidence history of the southern Victoria Land Basin into a quantitative geodynamic context and will assess the influence of flexure associated with late Neogene volcanic loading of the crust by the Erebus Volcanic Group. This will be done by extending geodynamic models of extension in the West Antarctic Rift System to include extensional hiatuses hypothesized to have occurred during the Late Paleogene and Miocene, and by developing a new geodynamic model of volcanic loading and associated lithosphere flexure. Finite element and finite difference modeling methods will be used. In the first phase of the project, a series of extensional geodynamic models will be developed to examine the effect that proposed extensional hiatuses have on the style of extension, with emphasis placed on developing a process based understanding of the change in rift style from diffuse during the Late Cretaceous to more focused during the Cenozoic. The models will test the hypotheses that extensional hiatuses led to the change in rifting style, and will place constraints on the timing and duration of the hiatuses. The second phase of the project will use the thermal and rheological properties of the previous models to constrain the flexural rigidity of the lithosphere in order to model the flexural response to volcanic loading to test the hypotheses that flexural subsidence contributed to cyclic changes between grounded and floating ice at the ANDRILL AND-1A site, complicating interpretations of the climatic record from this core, and that flexure contributes to the stress orientation at the AND-2B site, which is inconsistent with the expected regional extensional stress orientation.

Broader impacts:
The project will train an undergraduate student and an M.S. student. Outreach activities include a planned series of talks at regional high schools, junior colleges, and 4-year colleges that have geology programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to determine the pattern, amount, and timing of seafloor uplift and subsidence that occurred in response to volcano growth on Ross Island. Ross Island is located in the Ross Sea of West Antarctica, approximately 200-250 km from the ANDRILL Project drilling sites. Sediments recovered in the ANDRILL cores reveal a complex history involving sequential changes between grounded ice, floating ice, and open ocean that have been interpreted to indicate climatically driven fluctuations in the size of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet. This research investigates the possibility that changes between grounded and floating ice are a result of changes in seafloor depth due to flexure around Ross Island in response to volcanic loading rather than climatically driven changes in the thickness and extent of the ice sheet. The intellectual impact is refinement of interpretations of the ANDRILL sediment cores and their climatic implications. Results of this research indicate that emplacement of volcanic loads on Ross Island resulted in more than 100 m of seafloor uplift in the vicinity of the ANDRILL 2A drill hole. This is sufficient to result in a change from floating to grounded ice without requiring climatically induced changes in ice sheet size during periods of active volcanism on Ross Island. Broader impacts of the project include training of 4 graduate students and 2 undergraduate students in Antarctic tectonics and paleoclimate through their involvement as research assistants on the project. Results of the research have been incorporated in 3 classes at Colorado State University ranging from an introductory freshman geology class to graduate level classes in tectonics and subsurface geophysical mapping.
